docs.lead_paragraph: The settlement between Aetna U.S. Healthcare and the Texas attorney general that both sides called a ''landmark'' model for the rest of the nation has run into stiff opposition from some physicians and other state attorneys general. Aetna U.S. Healthcare, a unit of Aetna, the giant insurer based in Hartford, agreed last week to settle a lawsuit filed in Texas in 1998 by former Attorney General Dan Morales that accused it of providing improper financial incentives to doctors to limit patient care and other violations of Texas law.

headline.main: Physicians Find Fault With Aetna U.S. Healthcare Settlement in Texas

docs.abstract: Settlement between Aetna US Healthcare and Texas attorney general that both sides called 'landmark' model for rest of nation has run into stiff opposition from some physicians and other state attorneys general; Aetna agreed last week to settle lawsuit filed in Texas in 1998 by former Attorney General Dan Morales that accused firm of providing improper financial incentives to doctors to limit patient care and other violations of Texas law; physician groups and other critics, after studying details of agreement, which includes no fines, penalties or admissions of wrongdoing by Aetna, say settlement offers Aetna many loopholes and does little to change company's control of determining whether treatments are 'medically necessary'; John Cornyn, Texas attorney general, comments; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The wedding day was set, guests invited, and Linda Santarelli and Teddy Roland mused about a beach ceremony near their home in Loxahatchee, Fla. Then they learned of a new state law giving couples a marriage-license discount if they took a marital education class. More for the information than the price break, they said, they took a four-hour class last spring, a month before the wedding. By the end of it, they were convinced they were moving too fast.

headline.main: States Declare War On Divorce Rates, Before Any 'I Dos'

docs.abstract: Growing number of states require or encourage engaged couples to take marital education course out of concern about high social and economic costs of divorce; other initiatives include Wisconsin's hiring of 'marriage czar' to urge clergy to set requirements for engaged couples, and Arkansas's exploration of tax credit for couples taking marital course; Utah includes marital skills in high school curriculums, and Florida makes marital course high school graduation requirement; critics of such initiatives say government is meddling in marriage; close to half of marriages end in divorce; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: People hurt in traffic accidents actually recover more quickly when they cannot collect money for their pain and suffering, researchers say in a new study. The study supplies a strong medical argument for a no-fault insurance system, the researchers said in their report, published in today's issue of The New England Journal of Medicine.

headline.main: Faster Recovery Seen Under No-Fault Law

docs.abstract: Researchers say study finds people hurt in traffic accidents recover more quickly when they cannot collect money for their pain and suffering; study supplies strong medical argument for no-fault insurance system; study is in The New England Journal of Medicine (S)
docs.snippet: People hurt in traffic accidents actually recover more quickly when they cannot collect money for their pain and suffering, researchers say in a new study.    The study supplies a strong medical argument for a no-fault insurance system, the...

docs.lead_paragraph: The poor quality of doctors' handwriting has long been a source of jokes. But to Glen Tullman, chief executive of Allscripts, a company in Libertyville, Ill., doctors with poor penmanship are also a serious health risk. ''A significant number of medical errors come from physicians' handwriting,'' he said. ''When you rent a car they use a computer because they don't want to make an error. Here you're dealing with something that's a life-and-death issue.'' Mr. Tullman's company is one of a growing number trying to persuade doctors to dump handwritten prescriptions in favor of those produced by a wireless, handheld computer. Allscripts packages its TouchScript software in Hewlett-Packard Jornada Series 600 handheld computers, which use the Windows CE software system. Doctors use touch screen commands to write prescriptions and then send them electronically to patients' pharmacies. Before doctors choose a particular drug, they can also use the computer to review warnings about possible drug interactions and see if the product is covered by a patient's insurance.

headline.main: Look, Doc, No Pad! An Rx for Prescriptions

docs.abstract: Allscripts, Libertyville, Ill, packages its TouchScript software in Hewlewtt-Packard Series 600 handheld computers as means of enabling doctors, often known for having poor quality of handwriting, to write presecriptions and send them electronically to patients' pharmacies; cost of service to doctors is about $200 a month; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Adding to a series of recent proposals that he says are intended to give low-income people a firmer purchase on the American dream, Gov. George W. Bush today unveiled a plan to encourage private developers to build and rehabilitate houses in run-down, struggling neighborhoods. The incentive would be money: $1.7 billion, over five years, in federal tax credits for developers working in poor and moderate-income areas.

headline.main: Bush Unveils a Proposal to Encourage Development in Struggling Neighborhoods

docs.abstract: Gov George W Bush, campaigning in Battle Creek, Mich, calls for $1.7 billion in tax credits over five years for developers who build and rehabilitate houses in run-down, struggling neighborhoods; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On Super Bowl Sunday, viewers expected a spate of wacky commercials from the E*Trade Group, the upstart online broker, and they weren't disappointed. One spot showed a hospital patient who didn't have to worry about health insurance because he had ''money coming out the wazoo.'' But there was also a commercial about investing for the long term in which the hopes of a father who had counted on a cushy retirement financed by his son's career as a professional basketball player were dashed when his offspring suddenly confided a desire to enter show business. Another spot, centered on a disastrous disaster movie, reminded investors that knowing when to sell might be just as important as knowing when to buy.

headline.main: Wall St. Ads Taking Detour On Wary Path

docs.abstract: Marketers of financial products are moderating their pitches, playing down irrational exuberance in favor of counseling balance; they are cooling down considerably a category that had been positively giddy in its ebulliently optimistic assertions about how easy it is to make money by buying stocks and mutual funds; onslaught of such campaigns, primarily humorous, to promote brokers, online and traditional, has been one of most noticeable signs of galloping bull market; changes in some ad campaigns noted; photo (Advertising column) (M)
docs.snippet: On Super Bowl Sunday, viewers expected a spate of wacky commercials from the E*Trade Group, the upstart online broker, and they weren't disappointed. One spot showed a hospital patient who didn't have to worry about health insurance because he had...

docs.lead_paragraph: New Yorkers who belong to managed health care plans, including those enrolled in Medicare, were much more likely to receive cardiac surgery at hospitals with higher death rates for that surgery than those patients in traditional fee-for-service insurance plans, a study that will be released today in The Journal of the American Medical Association has found. The study, written by four doctors from Massachusetts and a professor at the State University of New York at Albany, concluded that among the 58,902 adults in New York State who underwent coronary artery bypass surgery between 1993 and 1996, more than 55 percent of those with fee-for-service insurance sought care in hospitals where death rates for that surgery were among the lowest. By contrast, only 40.8 percent of patients in managed care plans had the procedure in hospitals with such lower rates. Among Medicare patients enrolled in managed care, 36 percent underwent surgery at lower-risk hospitals.

headline.main: More Managed Care Clients Seen in Higher-Risk Hospitals

docs.abstract: Study to be released by Journal of American Medical Associaiton finds that New Yorkers who belong to managed health care plans, including those enrolled in Medicare, are much more likely to receive cardiac surgery at hospitals with higher death rates for that surgery than those patients in traditional fee-for-service insurance plans (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: EUROPE ITALY: PREMIER LOOKING TO QUIT -- With Prime Minister Massimo d'Alema appearing intent on announcing his resignation to Parliament today after losing regional elections on Sunday, his shaken coalition was ponderering whom to propose to try to form a new center-left majority. If Parliament does not approve a candidate, President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi will either appoint a caretaker government or call elections, now likely to favor the big winner in the regional vote, former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, above, leader of the center-right. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Drug Prices and Medicare'' (editorial, April 11): You rightly point out the ''alarming disparities in prescription drug costs'' between those Medicare recipients who have prescription insurance and those who don't. However, the unfairness of the two-tier pricing system is felt not only by the elderly but by everyone who does not have prescription benefits.
docs.abstract: Letter from Amy Lubensky says Apr 11 editorial noted disparities in prescription drug costs between Medicare recipients who have prescription insurance and those who do not; says two-tier pricing system is felt by everyone, not just elderly

docs.lead_paragraph: From 6 p.m. to 2 a.m. each night, Guadalupe Herrera cleans offices at that pinnacle of high-tech success, Cisco Systems, and then she heads home to the garage where she, her husband and two sons live. When Maria Godinez returns late each night from her $8-an-hour janitor's job at Sun Microsystems, she slips into the bedroom she shares with her husband and five children: part of a single-family house where four families and 22 people live.

headline.main: Janitors Struggle at the Edges of Silicon Valley's Success

docs.abstract: High-tech companies in California's Silicon Valley, which have created new class of stock option millionaire employees, have also given rise to class of janitors and other toilers who earn too little to afford decent housing in booming region; janitors, many of them illegal immigrants from Mexico or Central America, are caught between immigrant influx that puts downward pressure on wages and red-hot economy that pushes up housing costs; many are paying more than half of their monthly take home pay to live in garages; high-tech companies say janitors are employed by cleaning contractors and are not their responsibility; photos (M)
